user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_page_not_found:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_page_not_found (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  static const char page_content[] =
    "<html><head><title>Page Not Found</title></head>" \
    "<body>The requested page not found.</body></html>";
  static const size_t page_content_len =
    (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
  struct MHD_Response *resp;
  enum MHD_Result ret;

  resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len,
                                                 page_content);
  if (NULL == resp)
    return MHD_NO;

  /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
     without this header. */
  (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE,
                                  "text/html");

  ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_NOT_FOUND, resp);
  MHD_destroy_response (resp);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len,
                                                 page_content);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The array page_content is declared as 'static const char[]', so the pointer being passed is to a const-qualified type. Therefore the code itself does not violate Rule 8.13. A violation would occur if the prototype of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static expects a non-const pointer (e.g. void *); in that case passing page_content would discard the const qualifier and would violate Rule 8.13.
